title: Income and Deductions - 7 CFR § 273.9
excerpt: Households must meet both gross and net monthly income standards unless all members are elderly or disabled. Gross monthly income standards are set at 130 percent of the federal poverty level. Net monthly income standards are set at 100 percent of the federal poverty level.
keyProvisions: Gross income limit: 130% FPL
Net income limit: 100% FPL
Elderly/disabled households exempt from gross income test
Allowable deductions: standard, earned income, dependent care, medical, excess shelter

title: Household Concept - 7 CFR § 273.1
excerpt: Household means an individual who lives alone or who, while living with others, customarily purchases food and prepares meals for home consumption separate and apart from the others; or a group of individuals who live together and customarily purchase food and prepare meals together for home consumption.
keyProvisions: Household = people who purchase and prepare food together
Mandatory household members: spouses, children under 22
Optional household members: others living together

title: Immigrant Eligibility - 7 CFR § 273.4
excerpt: Qualified aliens who have been in qualified alien status for 5 years are eligible. Children under 18 who are qualified aliens are eligible without the 5-year waiting period.
keyProvisions: LPR eligible after 5 years
Children under 18: no waiting period
US citizens: always eligible
Refugees/asylees: eligible immediately

title: Verification Requirements - 7 CFR § 273.2(f)
excerpt: State agencies must verify certain factors prior to certification. Households must be given at least 10 days to provide required verification. The State agency must assist households in obtaining required verification provided the household is cooperating.
keyProvisions: Must verify: identity, residence, income, certain deductions
10-day minimum for providing verification
Agency must assist households in obtaining documents
Can pend application for missing verification

title: Standard Utility Allowances - 7 CFR § 273.9(d)(6)
excerpt: State agencies may develop standard utility allowances (SUAs) which vary by factors such as household size, type of residence, geographical area and climate. The SUA must be developed in accordance with the State's method approved by FNS.
keyProvisions: States set standard utility allowances
Can vary by household size, geography, climate
HCSUA (heating/cooling), BSUA (basic), limited utility allowance
Must be approved by FNS

title: Maryland SNAP Manual - Income Limits FY 2025
excerpt: Effective October 1, 2024, SNAP gross monthly income limits for Maryland are: 1 person - $1,580; 2 people - $2,137; 3 people - $2,694; 4 people - $3,250. Add $557 for each additional household member.
keyProvisions: FY 2025 income limits based on 130% FPL
Elderly/disabled: only net income test applies
Standard deduction: $198 (household size 1-3)
Maryland SUA: $180 (standard utility allowance)

title: Maryland SNAP State Options - Categorical Eligibility
excerpt: Maryland has elected broad-based categorical eligibility for households receiving TANF-funded services. Households are categorically eligible if they receive any TANF-funded benefit or service, regardless of the amount or duration.
keyProvisions: Broad-based categorical eligibility
TANF recipients automatically eligible
Asset limits waived for categorically eligible households
Gross income limit: 200% FPL for categorical eligibility

title: MAGI-Based Income - 42 CFR § 435.603
excerpt: For individuals whose financial eligibility is determined using modified adjusted gross income (MAGI), household income is calculated using the methodology specified in 26 CFR 1.36B-1(e). Household size is determined in accordance with 26 CFR 1.36B-3(d).
keyProvisions: MAGI = Modified Adjusted Gross Income (from tax return)
Household based on tax filing relationships
Excludes: SSI, VA disability, child support, Pell grants
Different rules for tax filers vs non-filers

title: Household Composition for MAGI - 42 CFR § 435.603(f)
excerpt: For the purposes of determining the household income of an individual using MAGI-based income, the household size is determined based on the expected tax filing status of the individual for the taxable year in which an initial determination or renewal of eligibility is being made.
keyProvisions: Tax filer household: self + spouse + tax dependents
Non-filer household: self + spouse + children under 19
Children: counted in parent's household if living together
Pregnant women: count unborn child(ren) in household size

title: Maryland Medicaid Eligibility - Income Limits 2025
excerpt: Maryland provides Medicaid coverage to adults aged 19-64 with MAGI up to 138% of the Federal Poverty Level. Children are covered under MCHP up to 322% FPL for children under 1, and 317% FPL for children 1-18.
keyProvisions: Adults: 138% FPL (expansion population)
Children under 1: 322% FPL
Children 1-18: 317% FPL
Pregnant women: 264% FPL
Aged/Blind/Disabled: separate non-MAGI rules

title: TANF Assistance - 45 CFR Part 260-265
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
excerpt: Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) provides cash assistance and supportive services to families with dependent children. States have broad discretion in designing their TANF programs, including setting income limits and benefit levels.
keyProvisions: Time limit: 60 months lifetime (federal)
Work requirements for able-bodied adults
States set income limits and benefit amounts
Must include dependent child in household

title: Maryland Temporary Cash Assistance (TCA) Standards
excerpt: Maryland TCA payment standards for 2024: 1 person - $488; 2 people - $604; 3 people - $727; 4 people - $824. Income deduction: $90 + 1/2 of remainder for employed individuals.
keyProvisions: Payment standards vary by household size
Earned income deduction: $90 + 50% of remainder
Work requirement: 30 hours/week
Dependent care deduction allowed
Time limit: 60 months (can be extended for hardship)

title: Low Income Home Energy Assistance - 42 USC § 8624
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
excerpt: States may set income eligibility for LIHEAP at the greater of 150 percent of the poverty level or 60 percent of the State median income. Benefits may be provided for heating, cooling, crisis assistance, and weatherization.
keyProvisions: Income limit: up to 150% FPL or 60% SMI (whichever higher)
States set their own limits within federal maximum
Categorical eligibility for SNAP, TANF, SSI recipients
Benefits for heating, cooling, crisis assistance

title: Maryland Office of Home Energy Programs - FY 2025-2026
excerpt: For the 2025-2026 program year, Maryland sets OHEP income eligibility at 175% of the Federal Poverty Level. Benefits range from $200 to $1,200 depending on household size, income, and heating type. Enhanced benefits available for elderly, disabled, and veteran households.
keyProvisions: Income limit: 175% FPL
Categorical eligibility: SNAP, TANF, SSI recipients
Benefit levels: $200-$1,200 based on income/heating type
Bonuses for: elderly (60+), disabled, veterans
Application period: August 1 - end of fiscal year

title: Earned Income Tax Credit - IRC § 32
excerpt: The earned income credit is a refundable tax credit for low and moderate-income working individuals and families. The amount of the credit varies based on income, filing status, and number of qualifying children.
keyProvisions: Refundable credit for low-income workers
Credit amount varies by: earned income, filing status, # of children
Max credit 2024: $7,830 (3+ children), $6,960 (2 children), $4,213 (1 child), $632 (no children)
Phaseout begins at different income levels by filing status

title: Child Tax Credit - IRC § 24
excerpt: The child tax credit is available for each qualifying child under age 17. For 2024, the credit is $2,000 per qualifying child. Up to $1,600 per child is refundable as the Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC).
keyProvisions: Credit: $2,000 per qualifying child under 17
Refundable portion (ACTC): up to $1,600 per child
Phaseout: $200,000 (single), $400,000 (MFJ)
Qualifying child: under 17, dependent, US citizen/resident

title: American Opportunity Tax Credit - IRC § 25A
excerpt: The American Opportunity Tax Credit provides a maximum annual credit of $2,500 per eligible student for qualified education expenses during the first four years of higher education. 40% of the credit (up to $1,000) is refundable.
keyProvisions: Credit: up to $2,500 per eligible student
Refundable portion: 40% (up to $1,000)
First 4 years of post-secondary education only
Covers tuition, fees, course materials

title: IRS Publication 4491 - VITA/TCE Training Guide
excerpt: The Volunteer Income Tax Assistance (VITA) program offers free tax help to people who generally make $64,000 or less, persons with disabilities, and limited English-speaking taxpayers. Volunteers must pass certification tests to prepare returns.
keyProvisions: Income limit: generally $64,000 or less
Free tax preparation and e-filing
Volunteers must be IRS-certified
Quality review required for all returns
Certification levels: Basic, Advanced, Military

title: IRS Publication 596 - Earned Income Credit
excerpt: Publication 596 provides detailed information about the Earned Income Credit (EIC), including eligibility requirements, how to figure the credit, and special situations. It includes worksheets and examples for calculating the credit amount.
keyProvisions: Detailed EITC eligibility rules
Special situations: military, clergy, disability
Investment income limit: $11,000
Must have valid SSN
Cannot be a qualifying child of another person

title: Maryland Earned Income Tax Credit
excerpt: Maryland provides a refundable state Earned Income Tax Credit equal to 45% of the federal EITC for taxpayers with qualifying children, and 100% of the federal EITC for taxpayers without qualifying children.
keyProvisions: With qualifying children: 45% of federal EITC
Without qualifying children: 100% of federal EITC
Fully refundable
Must qualify for federal EITC to claim state credit
Special provisions for military stationed in Maryland

title: Maryland Child Tax Credit
excerpt: Maryland provides a refundable Child Tax Credit of $500 per qualifying child under age 17. For low-income families (under $15,000 AGI), the credit is increased to $1,000 per child. Phaseout begins at $6,000 of tax liability.
keyProvisions: Standard credit: $500 per child under 17
Enhanced credit: $1,000 per child (AGI under $15,000)
Refundable credit
Same qualifying child definition as federal CTC
Phaseout for higher-income taxpayers

title: Veterans Disability Compensation - 38 USC § 1110
excerpt: The Secretary shall pay compensation for disability resulting from personal injury suffered or disease contracted in line of duty, or for aggravation of a preexisting injury or disease in line of duty, in the active military, naval, or air service.
keyProvisions: Compensation for service-connected disabilities
Rating from 10% to 100% based on severity
Monthly compensation varies by rating and dependents
Tax-free benefit
Separate from retirement pay

title: VA Benefit Exclusion from Income - 38 USC § 5301
excerpt: Payments of benefits due or to become due shall not be assignable except to the extent specifically authorized by law, and such payments made to, or on account of, a beneficiary shall be exempt from taxation, from the claim of creditors, and shall not be liable to attachment, levy, or seizure.
keyProvisions: VA benefits exempt from federal taxation
Protected from creditors and garnishment
Cannot be assigned or seized
Excluded from income calculations for federal benefit programs
Applies to: disability, pension, education, vocational rehab

title: VA Disability Income Exclusion - 7 CFR § 273.9(c)(11)
excerpt: Exclude any payments from the Department of Veterans Affairs that are specifically excluded from consideration as income by any other Federal statute, including compensation for service-connected disability and dependency and indemnity compensation.
keyProvisions: VA disability compensation excluded from SNAP income
VA pension excluded from SNAP income
Dependency and indemnity compensation excluded
Exclusion based on 38 USC § 5301
Veterans may be categorically eligible for SNAP

title: 2025 Federal Poverty Guidelines
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
excerpt: The 2025 Federal Poverty Guidelines for the 48 contiguous states and DC: 1 person - $15,060; 2 persons - $20,440; 3 persons - $25,820; 4 persons - $31,200. For each additional person, add $5,380.
keyProvisions: Updated annually
Base for calculating income eligibility (e.g., 130% FPL, 138% FPL)
Different guidelines for Alaska and Hawaii
Used for SNAP, Medicaid, LIHEAP, and other federal programs
Effective for programs using FY 2025 guidelines
